Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. John Banta
Address: 82 Main Street
Birthplace: Carlton Co., Minnesota

1. Introductory Questions
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1917
   Where did you set up housekeeping? Homestead, Northfield Division
   Where had you been living before that? Duluth, Minnesota
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
   How far was it to your nearest store? Eleven miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice a month
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
   Flour, sugar, coffee, rice, oatmeal, salt
   Dried peas & beans and some dried fruit

2. Flour and Other Grain Products
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood
   In what quantities did you buy it? One hundred pound bags
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About 2.50
   How much did you use graham flour? Very little
   Whole wheat flour? None
   Was flour milled locally? No. How far away? _______ that year? _______
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? _______
   What other grain products did you use? _______
   Cornmeal? No. Whole wheat? No. Farina? Same
   Other? _______
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Sometimes
   How did you grind it? Coffee grinder
Mrs. John Ranta

Address: Hamilton, Pa., Pennsylvania

1. TERRITORY LISTING

What year did you start homesteading in Indiana County? (1917)

How far did you go to hunt for timber? (Hamilton, Pennsylvania)

For how many people did you prepare meals? (5)

How far was it to your nearest store? (Hamilton, Pennsylvania)

How often would you visit by foot to the store? (Weekly)

What groceries did you usually buy in town during a year? (Flour, sugar, coffee, rice, oatmeal, salt, dried peas & beans and some dried fruit)

2. FOODS USED

In what quantities did you buy flour? (One hundred pounds)

Was there any other food product of Mrs. Ranta's? (Yes)

How much did you use cracker flour? (Very little)

Was flour killed locally? (Yes)

Did you purchase any other similar products? (No)

Corn meal? (Yes)

Oats? (Yes)

Did you grind your own wheat for yourselves? (Yes)

How did you grind it? (Grinder)
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 2.0 lb bag
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? 7.0 cents
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Golden Roger's
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 5 lb
At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? Yes
Butter? Yes Eggs? Yes
What was the price of butter? 15¢ of eggs? About 10¢
Did you pick eggs for hens? Some How? In crates
Did you make butter? Yes Cheese? No
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Hog
How did you get fresh meat? Very little
How often did you get fresh meat? Once a month
How did you preserve meat? Cured
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? After 1926
If so what year was it organized? About 1926
Did you use game? No What kinds?
For how long?
What part did fish play in the family diet?
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured & fresh in winter
Kinds? Whitefish and salt herring

### 12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ________Well________ in the yard_____________________

How far was this water from your house? ________________________________

How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank) _______carried by pail________

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

No change. Still use well water carried by pail or brought near house in a barrel.

Was it brought to the house? (e.g., barrel, tank) (Answer by first)

no change. Still use well water, answer

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Buy and made some.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Fels naptha and Prt & G.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Prairie chips in summer.

Where did you get your fuel? Coal and wood bought in town...for winter use.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

No prairie chips are used anymore. Same supply of coal and wood as during first years.

Have you ever returned to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

No.

We have always had such necessary foods as milk and butter, chicken and pork grown on the place ever since we started on the homestead. Also potatoes and vegetables such as keep for part of the winter. We have always used a lot of milk, as beverage and feedings etc.

Shortage of fuel was our greatest problem and for the first few years used prairie chips in summer. The coal and wood prices being almost prohibitive, and used only during the cold weather. Money was scarce so we tried to cut fuel costs to a minimum.
Morning, the 1920s dried fruits were packed in convenient 5 oz. packages. You will notice

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

The one outstanding article in preparing meals is the pressure cooker of today, which can be used even in remote areas where no power is available. The small gas stoves are now in common use and certainly are convenient especially during the hot months.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In the last ten years such foods as Lipton's Soups that come in envelopes and other soups in cans are wonderful help in preparing meals.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use back of page if more space is needed.
The one outstanding article in preparing meals is the pressure cooker of today which can be used even in remote areas where no power is available. The small gas plants are now common and certainly an convenience especially during the hot month.

In the last two years much food has been prepared by home economics classes and other groups in same and wonderful help in preparing meals.

Plants and other plants have been grown under various types of hydroponic systems and results obtained show quality, methods of merchandising, and possibilities for storage, preservation and other details. (This book of)
